title: Research
text: Department of Biological Sciences|California State Polytechnic University, Pomona

title: Research
text:
Abstract
The demand for prosthetics has gradually increased with the advancements in technology, making them more accessible to the growing population in the United States. Prosthetic recipients have become increasingly younger over time, resulting in a longer duration of implant use among this demographic. The extended implant duration can result in corrosion of the metal alloy, creating an inflammatory response which can lead to loosening of the implant due to bone resorption. Bone resorption is the process of bone tissue dissolving through the action of specialized cells called osteoclasts. Monocytes and macrophages are precursors for osteoclast cells. One of the key signals in osteoclast formation is the Receptor Activator of Nuclear factor Kappa beta (NFkB ligand), also known as RANKL. This ligand plays a crucial role by binding to the RANK receptors found on the surface of monocytes/macrophages promoting differentiation of osteoclasts. Mature osteoclasts will attach to the bone surface and secrete hydrochloric acid that degrades the bone, causing osteolytic loosening. Different cell types are involved in the activation of bone resorption including osteoclasts, macrophages and fibroblasts, but it is not entirely known how neutrophils play a role in this process. Neutrophils are one of the first responders of the immune system in the presence of an antigen. They secrete many of the same cytokines as macrophages and fibroblasts that aid in osteoclast activation. It is unknown how neutrophils respond to the metals directly or if they induce an inflammatory response. This study seeks to provide more knowledge on neutrophil function in the presence of new metal alloys that could potentially be used for prosthetic implants. HL-60 cells differentiated into neutrophil-like cells (NLCs) will be exposed to titanium, titanium-aluminum-vanadium alloys (Ti-6Al-4V), and novel boron-titanium alloys. Upon exposure, phagocytosis activity will be analyzed
